TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicant was born in DATE and lives in FAC .

CARDINAL . He was employed by ORG where he worked in the catering service . In DATE he received his employment booklet ( radna knjižica ) by registered mail , and his employer had noted in it that his employment had been terminated on DATE . Enclosed with it , for the applicant to sign , was a draft mutual agreement to terminate his employment , reference no . CARDINAL - CARDINAL - CARDINAL/CARDINAL - CARDINAL/CARDINAL - CARDINAL , dated DATE and signed by the employer .

CARDINAL . The applicant refused to sign the draft agreement . Instead , on DATE he made a request to the employer for the protection of his rights ( zahtjev za zaštitu prava ) arising from the employment relationship . However , no formal decision was given by the employer in response to the applicant 's request . Rather , in a letter of CARDINAL DATE the applicant was merely notified that his employment had been terminated because the catering service of ORG had been outsourced to a third party for whom the applicant had refused to work .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant brought a civil action in ORG ( PERSON ) seeking reinstatement . He argued that his employment had been terminated against his will as he had never agreed with the employer to terminate it . Thus , the employer 's actions had amounted to a dismissal , which was unlawful since no formal decision had been issued .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG , considering that ORG was competent to hear the applicant 's case , declined jurisdiction in the matter and declared his action inadmissible . On DATE ORG ( PERSON ) dismissed the applicant 's appeal and upheld the first - instance decision . On DATE ORG ( PERSON ) declared inadmissible the applicant 's subsequent appeal on points of law ( revizija ) against the second - instance decision . The case was then transferred to ORG .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG ( Upravni sud PERSON ) issued a decision whereby it invited the applicant 's representative to specify which decision , that is , which administrative act , the applicant was challenging , and to submit CARDINAL copies of it . The decision read as follows :

“ In the administrative dispute of the plaintiff PERSON ... against the decision of the respondent , ORG ) concerning the termination of his employment , [ the plaintiff 's ] representative is invited , within the meaning of CARDINAL of LAW , to provide this court within DATE with :

- an express statement indicating which specific administrative act he is contesting by his action – it is necessary to indicate the [ reference ] number of the act , as well as its date of issue , and to provide this court with CARDINAL copies of that decision .
If the [ plaintiff 's ] representative does not correct the above shortcomings of the action , the court will declare it inadmissible as deficient . ”
On DATE the applicant 's representative replied as follows :

“ Acting upon the decision of the [ ORG ] of DATE , the plaintiff states that he is unable to indicate the specific [ reference ] number of the administrative act , that is to say , a potential decision , because such an act has never been issued by the respondent and the plaintiff 's employment contract was terminated in the manner indicated and described in the statement of claim [ ( ' u tužbi ' ) ] [ of CARDINAL DATE ] . ”
On DATE ORG declared the applicant 's action inadmissible , finding that he had failed to rectify the shortcomings of his action as requested .

CARDINAL . The applicant then lodged a constitutional complaint against ORG decision . On DATE ORG ( Ustavni sud PERSON ) dismissed the applicant 's complaint and served its decision on his representatives on CARDINAL DATE .

CARDINAL . On DATE a certain PERSON , who had also been employed by ORG and dismissed in the same way as the applicant , brought a civil action in ORG seeking reinstatement . She was represented by an advocate from the same law firm as the advocate who represented the applicant in the above proceedings . In her action ORG explained that she used to work in the catering service of ORG and that on DATE she had received her employment booklet by registered mail and her employer had noted in it that her employment had been terminated on DATE . Enclosed with it , for her to sign , was a draft mutual agreement to terminate her employment , no . CARDINAL - CARDINAL - CARDINAL - CARDINAL/CARDINAL - CARDINAL , dated DATE and signed by the employer . ORG further explained that she had refused to sign the draft agreement . Instead , she had made a request to the employer for the protection of her rights arising from the employment relationship . However , no formal decision had been given by the employer in response to her request . Rather , in a letter of CARDINAL DATE she had merely been notified that her employment had been terminated because the catering service of ORG had been outsourced to a third party .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG , considering that ORG was competent to hear the plaintiff 's case , declined jurisdiction in the matter and declared her action inadmissible . On DATE ORG dismissed her appeal and upheld the first - instance decision . The case was then transferred to ORG .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG issued a decision whereby it invited the plaintiff 's representative to specify which decision , that is , which administrative act , the plaintiff was challenging , and to submit CARDINAL copies of it .
CARDINAL . On DATE the plaintiff 's representative replied to the court 's request . The relevant part of her reply read as follows :

“ On the basis of its mutual agreement on the termination of employment contract number : CARDINAL - CARDINAL - CARDINAL - CARDINAL/CARDINAL - CARDINAL of DATE , which agreement was signed only by the respondent ... , the respondent recorded the termination of employment in the plaintiff 's employment booklet , and on DATE the plaintiff received the employment booklet and the [ abovementioned draft ] mutual agreement by registered mail .

The plaintiff made a request to the respondent for the protection of her rights but on DATE she received notification that her employment relationship with the respondent had been terminated because the respondent no longer provided catering services .

Since the provisions of LAW prescribe that a written mutual agreement on the termination of an employment contract constitutes a legal way to terminate the employment contract if both parties sign it , and given that the plaintiff refused to sign the [ abovementioned draft ] mutual agreement , [ that agreement ] can not be considered to have been concluded and could not have produced any legal effect . The respondent could only have dismissed the plaintiff for business reasons by giving her notice . Therefore , the termination of employment in question and the rescission of the employment contract represents a flagrant breach of the employee 's rights because the respondent – contrary to the legislation in force – unilaterally rescinded the plaintiff 's employment contract on the basis of a ' mutual agreement ' the plaintiff did not sign and was not obliged to sign . ”

The plaintiff 's representative also emphasised that ORG had already declined jurisdiction in the case and invited ORG , should it find that it did not have jurisdiction either , to apply to ORG in order to resolve the conflict of jurisdiction with the ordinary courts thereby created .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG , considering that it did not have jurisdiction to examine the case , applied to ORG to resolve the conflict of jurisdiction with the ordinary courts . In its application the court wrote , inter alia :

“ .. [ It ] is undisputed that the plaintiff concluded an employment contract of unlimited duration with the respondent on DATE and that the respondent tried to rescind that contract by a mutual agreement ... which the plaintiff did not sign and which can not in any case constitute an administrative act ... for which reason ORG can not decide on [ its ] lawfulness .

This case does not concern a dispute where a decision on a right of a civil servant or an employee employed by a state organ is being contested . Rather , it concerns a mutual agreement on the termination of an employment contract , and its lawfulness can not be reviewed by ORG . ”
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG ruled that ORG was the competent court to hear the ORG 's case .

CARDINAL . The Administrative Disputes Act ( Zakon o upravnim sporovima , ORG of ORG no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL , and ORG nos . CARDINAL/CARDINAL , CARDINAL/CARDINAL and DATE ) regulates the procedure before ORG and in its relevant part provides as follows :
Section CARDINAL ) provides that the proceedings before ORG ( that is , an administrative dispute ) may be initiated only against an administrative act .

Section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) provides that an administrative act , within the meaning of that LAW , is an act whereby a state organ in the exercise of public authority decides on a right or obligation of an individual or an organisation in some administrative matter .
Section ORG ) provides that a statement of claim must indicate , inter alia , the contested administrative act and must be accompanied by the original or a copy of the contested act .

Section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) provides that if the action is incomplete or incomprehensible , the president of the panel shall invite the plaintiff to correct the shortcomings within a certain time - limit . In doing so , the president should instruct the plaintiff what has to be done and how and warn him or her of the consequences of failing to comply with the court 's request .

Section CARDINAL ) provides that if the plaintiff does not correct the shortcomings of his action within the time - limit fixed , and they are of such a nature as to prevent the court proceeding with the case , the court shall declare the action inadmissible as deficient .
Section CARDINAL provides that if LAW does not contain specific provisions on the procedure before ORG ( that is , in administrative disputes ) , the provisions of LAW should apply mutatis mutandis .
Sections CARDINAL - CARDINAL provide for the remedy of reopening proceedings before ORG and regulate the procedure following a petition for reopening .

CARDINAL . The relevant part of LAW ( Zakon o parničnom postupku , ORG of ORG nos . CARDINAL , CARDINAL/CARDINAL ( corrigendum ) , CARDINAL , CARDINAL/CARDINAL , CARDINAL/CARDINAL , DATE , DATE , DATE , CARDINAL/CARDINAL and CARDINAL/CARDINAL , and ORG nos . CARDINAL , GPE , CARDINAL , CARDINAL , CARDINAL/CARDINAL , CARDINAL , CARDINAL , CARDINAL/CARDINAL , CARDINAL and GPE ) , as in force at the relevant time , provided as follows :

“ If the court to which the case has been transferred ... considers that the court which has transferred the case or some other court has jurisdiction , it shall refer the case to the court competent to resolve that conflict of jurisdiction ... ”
“ The conflict of jurisdiction between courts of different types shall be resolved by ORG . ”

“ ( CARDINAL ) When ORG has found a violation of a human right or fundamental freedom guaranteed by LAW or additional protocols thereto ratified by GPE , a party may , within DATE of the finality of the judgment of ORG , file a petition with the court in GPE which adjudicated in the first instance in the proceedings in which the decision violating the human right or fundamental freedom was rendered , to set aside the decision by which the human right or fundamental freedom was violated .
( CARDINAL ) The proceedings referred to in paragraph CARDINAL of this section shall be conducted by applying , mutatis mutandis , the provisions on the reopening of proceedings .
( CARDINAL ) In the reopened proceedings the courts are required to respect the legal opinions expressed in the final judgment of ORG finding a violation of a fundamental human right or freedom . ”
